comments.body: THAT IS SOOOOOOOOOOOOO GREAT MATE
This might not be implemented as biomes are supposed to be “painted on to already existing terrain,” but I could see biomes only being in certain terrain.

The wetland biome could be a small area of a few chunks where you could find sphagnum moss/ peat. It would be cool if the wetland biome was one you could grow and nurture from a small area and get it to expand by looking after it. This could be done by letting the peat spread onto mud blocks next to it at a similar pace to the oxidation of copper. This would be a great way to raise awareness for the value of peat habitats in stopping climate change, while adding a new fun way to play the game. If the player expands the biome more mobs should start to spawn in the wetland and the water in the biome if moved somewhere else could make crops and other plants grow faster because of all the nutrients in it. Developing peat could have the same property as powdered snow letting the player move through it but if something dies in it then it could leave bonemeal instead of its regular drop.
good idea

Visuals aren't everything (although I totally agree with you). Part of what makes the adventure aspect of exploration underwhelming is the lack of actually interesting things to find and collect. Other than structures, which usually have loot chests, most biomes don't have very many unique blocks/items that can be obtained (since they're either farmable, or craft-able in other ways). I would love to see more biome specialty items, blocks, and plants that aren't found anywhere else.
This is a bit Op to be honest since wither skeleton heads are pretty rare and end crystal is meant to be made rather than traded
Good idea, just not those specific items. They are too rare, and if you could get them from other dimension villagers then that would just be OP. Overall, good idea.
I like this idea!

then it would be fine i do like the idea though

Yes! Minecraft needs overall more birds and this is an excellent opportunity to add one. They could also add a mechanic where the crows starts make more noise to warn the player of the presence of creaking.

Crows or ravens, only makes noise during daytime and silent/asleep at night for the eerie biome's intended atmosphere. Corvids should be tameable with the ability to bring shiny small gifts (as they do in actuality).

The copyright issues with Mojang and Telltale are complex. Since Telltale games has gone out of business, and support for MCSM has stopped, perhaps some of the ideas could be picked up by Mojang. Telltale and Mojang were in negotiations for the game, and it is a shared venture, to an extent, like other video games based off of movies, where the rights were given to a third-party. Correct me if I'm wrong please!
and Maybe some glowing obsibion.

This brings back vibes of Skyblock. There's something very satisfying about expanding and sculpting a small new world. I have some suggestions to polish the idea.

Purpur blocks are made of chorus fruit (eating it makes you teleport). The portal could be made of purpur blocks in a ring on the ground. Throwing an ender eye above the portal could cause it to fly in and activate it. The inner dimension should have a linked portal made of bedrock, like the dragon fountain in the end. The dimension could be a flat, floating end island with a blackish skybox, similar to the end. No creepy, glitchy music - just silence. It is just for building a secret base.

I don't really think this should be a private dimension though - just a secret one. The portal should link to a dimension that was created for the player that activated it. Each of that player's portals should link to the same personal dimension, same island, same bedrock landing pad. When they exit the dimension they should teleport to the oldest, still active portal that was created by them. This provides an almost instant method of 1 way teleportation.

There should be one dimension per player and they can be accessed by any portal that was activated by that player. Players are free to visit other player's portals and their linked dimensions. If a griefer deactivates the last portal, players inside will teleport back to that location by default anyway. If a griefer reactivates a portal, it links to their own dimension. Thus dimensions can be protected by a player by just deactivating them. If that doesn't work, just have have the current chunk determine which dimension a portal links to.
This'll be great for maps and stuff

this is great i agree it shouldnt be "personal" but what if when you enter the pocket dimension the portal closes behind who ever turns the portal on. so you turn it on friend goes through  then you then it closes. depending on who turns on the portal determines whos pocket dimension is opened. a friend can leave the pocket dimension by turning on portal inside but if they turn on portal in over wolrd its there own pocket dimension. i think it should be an infinite plane of a single layer of bedrock for all six sides. no mobs at all unless they enter from the over world.

also i think this would be great to add into my idea of an astral realm that i posted in this catagory. finding the resources there in order to build this makes it super late game content.
dont forget to add its stairs, walls, and slab varients too!

was about to post this idea untill i saw your post. I agree, it doesn't look new at all

Expanding the trunk thickness and adding holes/openings through some of the trunks, where upon entry, randomly teleports you elsewhere within a certain radius (much like the chorus fruit mechanic). This can disorientate the player but also help them frantically escape the creaking (if they are buffed or swarmed). An interesting story telling structure within the garden such as a fountain made of end bricks, perhaps alludes to the idea that these 'rifts' within the trees reflect a weakened overworld stability in this biome and are connected to the end dimension. This gives reasoning also for its pale tone, as if its life is being absorbed by these rifts.

(raising the canopy height will allow for thicker trailing vines to help them look more alike weeping willow trees, and also grants creativity for the shape of the openings within some trunks). 

This makes the biome extremely unique, fits within the disorienting nature of the sound affects, and brings a unique way of countering being swarmed by the creaking (allows them to have a buff). It also allows them to be given a useful drop to create a strong reason to collect the heart as a spawner. With the creaking & rift (chorus) teleportation, in its own right is already a fun challenge to dart around trying to draw the mobs away for you to get closer to the heart.

edit: also makes sense why the creaking look like they do (similar to the enderman) if the end dimesnsion is disrupting this biome and morphing its mobs
I also agree, if they could make it look even more like a willow that would be cool. It should not be an identical desaturated copy of Dark Oak.

I think the base (bottom 2-3 blocks of trunk) should remain 2x2 (to help camouflage the Creaking) but a more asymmetrical upper trunk, branches & leaf arrangement would give it a more unique identity. The texture for the Pale Oak sapling shown had a twisty look to it, would be great if the grown trees also reflected this.

I'd way rather they made the trees actually look like Willow trees, which they referenced in the reveal trailer.

Because they mentioned them as inspiration, yet they look nothing like Willow Trees.

Yes. Any difference in tree generation design from the Dark Oak would be preferred, but specifically, a more "Weeping Willow" esque design, just as the creators said where their inspiration came from, would be much needed to ensure the Pale Gardens aren't just a desaturated Dark Oak Forest.
